Million years ago: I was 19 waiting for a bus, I was carrying a lot of stuff, and in a hectic moment, I left my purse at the bus stop. I had no money, no ID, no credit cards. I got home and received a voice mail "hey I think I found your purse" he told me his name and his phone number ... this young man was also a student at my college. I called him and retrieved my purse, all the money was there, of course. Then a couple days later I called the main number for the frat he lived in and asked "Does he like beer? if so what is his favorite beer?" -- "Killian's Red" so I dropped off a case of Killian's at his frat and put a note "good deeds are their own reward, and sometimes you also get beer, thank you!!"

Good parenting.  In 1976 my father found a woman's purse, containing $3500 (Canadian) left in a shopping cart in a grocery store parking lot. He looked around, saw nobody and locked it in his car. He said to Mom, "We'll take it to the police station on our way home."  When they returned to the car, they saw an old lady crying and a cop writing in his notebook. She had taken that money out of the bank for her and her husband to live on in Florida for the winter. Dad walks up to him; "Lost purse? I have it in my car." Cop closes his notebook and says, "Ma'am, you're lucky an honest man found it."  My parents also took in unemployed young men from out of province who came to Toronto looking for work. Mom would do their laundry and cook for them. When she died early from cancer, a number of them came to her funeral and openly wept: "She was like a mother to us when we had nowhere to live."  God bless good parents; we need more of them.

This young man did all the right things, including thinking about the rules of life his mother taught him.   So, why did he take the money.  When you find something that is not yours you simply return it, that is part of being a good human, doing what is right.    The feeling behind returning something lost and knowing that the person is happy, should  be enough for him.  And, this woman should never have offered him any money, and let him know what doing a simple good deed is, without reward.   It is a lesson in life that all humans should experience.   Money is not a replacement of simply doing what is right.   Teach our children better, so they grown up to know better.      Teach an adult better, so they continue to know what is simply the right thing to do, and there should be no other reward.    There is no REWARD needed, expected, given or taken.   Just do what is right, what is the big deal?

A breath of fresh air
Proof that being good rewards us better than being evil.  Romans 12:21: "Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.". This verse encourages believers to respond to evil with acts of kindness and righteousness, rather than allowing evil to defeat them.  Romans 12:20 (NIV): "If your enemies are hungry, feed them. If they are thirsty, give them something to drink. In doing this, you will heap burning coals of shame on their heads," according to the NIV. This verse provides a specific example of how to overcome evil with good, by showing kindness to those who are your enemies.  The passage emphasizes the importance of choosing good over evil and actively working against the effects of evil in the world.  It suggests that good actions, even in response to evil, can have a powerful impact on others, potentially shaming them into changing their ways.  Some Bible commentaries on the verse note that "overcoming evil with good" is a proactive approach to dealing with negativity, rather than a passive acceptance of it.

I own a Classic Car dealership and 7 years ago I caught a 15 year old kid breaking into one of my parts sheds intending on stealing some parts, He said he was only doing it to be able to buy food for him and brother, their father was in prison and their mom was strung out on drugs and didn;t care about anything else. I called the police but the reason I did was because I had a plan. When the cops got there I had  the kid sitting inside the shop and I told the police officer the deal and that I didn't call to have him arrested, I wanted his help to help the kids. He called CPS and we all came up with a plan, they went and got the younger brother that was 11 at time, and they left the boys with me temporarily until they could get something on paper. I ended becoming their foster dad, Andre just finished his 1st enlistment in the Air Force and going to college under the "Stripes to Bars Program" Deshuan is going in the Air Force as soon as he graduates in couple weeks.

Good on you young man.
That good feeling he got returning it far outweighed whatever money was in there.
Many years ago, I worked for a landscaping company and we were trimming shrubs at a Denny's restaurant off the interstate. I was 17. I found a purse in the bushes. It had been there for a very long time and it was full of stuff. No cash, but credit cards, bills, makeup, ID, photos of family.  She lived in a different state. I took it home and proceeded to call every number in her address book or on a bill to try and find her. (This was before computers.) I finally reached her old landlord who had her call me. She was an older Hispanic lady and she couldn't believe that I had gone thru all that trouble. She explained, in broken English that 5 years ago, she and family were eating at the restaurant, she went to the ladies room,  left her purse in the seat and never saw it again. She gave me a forwarding address and I mailed it back to her. I felt so good to do that deed.
What A Young Man Of Integrity! May God Continue To Bless This Young King ğŸ’—

I once found a wallet on the side of the road outside of a Walmart. After some Facebook searching, I was able to contact the owner. She hadn't yet realized her wallet was missing. I returned her wallet with everything inside, debit card, government benefits card, and her crisp $100 bill. She didn't even check inside to see if I had stolen anything. She just thanked me and handed me a $20 bill. I declined the money at first, but she insisted. She had a new born in her arms. I'm sure it would have bene a tough day for her to lose that wallet. I always smile when I think about walking up and returning it.

It all sounds great! But life is strange... I once spotted a, womans wallet. In the center of the road, where some plowed snow, and ice was melting away... I turned around, and retrieved it. It was full of stuff. I went home and  looked through it, for a number to call. There was a liscence, with a 16 year old owner, inside it. I found a number on something, and called it. The people, that answered were her parents. I told them the story, and they asked me if my intentions were just to meet the young girl? Then the mother said, I guess it was empty! I said nothing, I was speechless. I gave them my address, and stated that I really could understand, their concearn for her, and 2:05 2:05  agreed to return the wallet. When they arrived, the "mother" only rolled down the truck window, partway. I handed it to her and said, You were wrong... it wasnt empty... there was $125.00 dollars in it... which I left inside it, just where it was! As I handed it through the window slot, she snatched it, and closed the window, as they drove away...  No, thank you, not even a word... I have returned  numerous purses, wallets and valuables to customers when I was driving a cab. Some were very grateful and some didnâ€™t even care to properly thank me. Iâ€™m going to tell both experiences. 1. The bad one: after my shifts end, I walked up stairs of the building to my apartment, I found a purse with lots of stuff in it. From the id , I was able to pull a phone # off the phone book, there was no cell phones back thenğŸ˜Š. It turned out to be from a different city. So I called on my land line, had to pay expensive long distance later. An elderly woman answered, she said itâ€™s her daughterâ€™s she still uses her address, but lived in my building. So I got the apt #, took the elevator, knocked at her door, she opened it, and I explained what I went through to find her. She literally snatched out of my hand , with a cold thanks you barely hear, looked like she forced herself to say it, then slammed the door shut .   2. I pick up a university student waved at me, dropped her in a house party that was like 100 students gathered on that evening. Once I made it back to where I normally park, I realized she left a purse. I looked for id, got a name, the purse was full of cash, credit cards, valuables. Quickly drove back and asked for her name without saying why Iâ€™m there. So a guy went inside, shortly, she came out , as soon as she saw me, she ran towards me and I handed over her purse. She was so happy, she kept hugging me. I said open the purse, check for everything before I leave because I opened it to find your id and name. She did and cried from happiness. She mentioned that the money was going towards her rent and her expenses for that month. She insisted to give me as much as I ask for. I laughed and replied, â€œ but I couldâ€™ve got all your money if I didnâ€™t have to return it, but that belongs to youâ€.  I tried to leave but she did not let me go , forcefully handed $200 . But I refused that amount. At the end, I just took $40.  People, if you find something, return it, as you want thing be returned to you when you loose them.

In about 2006 my husband of 31 years passed away leaving me to raise our two daughters ages 12 and 14 myself. We decided to go out to a local park to go swimming a few months after the funeral, and I was kind of out of it but I wanted the girls to have fun. But I was in full-blown grieving. I was not firing at all cylinders. I left my wallet on the pay booth where you have to pay five dollars to get into the park. I didnâ€™t realize it till about an hour later and I went back the wallet was gone. I had a lot of cash in that wallet and I needed it. I thought â€œwell that sucksâ€¦ Iâ€™m gonna have to call the police and report everything stolenâ€¦â€œ And I started crying. but just by chance I thought well maybe somebody turned it in probably not but Iâ€™ll check with the park attendant. Lo and behold they HAD turned it in. I had $300+ in cash in that wallet and a bunch of credit cards. Nothing was touched. I never knew who did it and if I did I wouldâ€™ve done something nice for them but God saw it and he has made note of it.â¤

Glad the kid was trustworthy, and glad that he was treated properly when he returned the purse. I once had a very different experience returning a lost purse, 60 some-odd years ago. My girlfriend (now my wife of 62 years) and I went 'parking' in a remote corner of a park that was a popular place for teenaged daliances, most of which naturally took place at night. But I worked nights and we were there on a warm sunny afternoon. We went for a walk along the shore of the pond, and I happened to notice a purse barely sticking out from under a bush. Picked it up, found the wallet and ID. Turned out the girl lived a couple towns away, so the next day, I drove over there and rang the bell. Asked if she lived there, and the lady who answered the door said I'd better talk to her husband. She calls him, and he comes to the door and basically accuses me of having my way with his daughter and stealing her purse.  He wanted to see MY drivers license. Finally, he called her to inspect the contents to "see what this guy might have stolen" from it. She said everything was in order, and her cash was still in the wallet.  The guy was still beside himself, refused to believe either of us when we insisted that we'd never met, and told me that if I ever went near his daughter again he'd have me arrested. I occasionally wonder whatever happened to her, because from what I could see, her home life was none too happy.
For acts like this rewards are far greater than money, God Bless this young man, there is hope for humanity yet ğŸ™

In 1989 I went to a store to get candy for a friend "Rickys" Birthday Party I was riding my bike too soon after. I'm Italian, Friend Ricky was Hispanic. I'm standing in line at a store and the man in front of me drops cash as he pulled out his wallet from his back pocket. I grab the cash off the ground and tap the man on the shoulder. He doesn't speak English very well, but He got the idea. The man thanked me, gave me $5 which was a lot to a kid in the 80's and paid for my Stuff. The guy at the store was Ricky's father.

A couple of years ago, my wife and I (btw we live in San Diego) went to BC, Canada. On our way to Whistler, we stopped at a McDs for brkfast, at a small town. Afterwards we drove around a little, then I had to use the bathroom. We found a public park that had a restroom. As we continued on our trip, I realized I don't have my phone. So we traced our moves backwards. I went to the public restroom and there was a note on the door about a phone found and a number to call. I called the number and went to the meeting place. It turned out to be a homeless shelter. The guy who found my phone lives there. I tried to offer him money but he wouldn't accept, so I gave it to the people running the place for their feeding program. I'll never forget this experience.

"A Boyâ€™s Good Deed Takes a Dark Turn, Ending in Arrest"   What began as a feel-good story of teenage kindness has taken a surprising and tragic twist. A 17-year-old boy gained internet fame after returning a lost bag he found at a mall to its owner, an act that was captured on a home security camera and widely shared on social media. Inspired by his honesty, thousands of people donated to him, raising $19,000. But the boyâ€™s newfound fame took a sinister turn. Instead of using the funds for good, he funneled the money into building a criminal network involved in drugs and prostitution. The dark transformation came to light when authorities arrested him, exposing how an act of kindness spiraled into a life of crime.

So, We had a company come paint our office at work mostly during after hours. I come into work one day and go to use our restroom and i immediately see a wallet right in the center of the floor.  I was first to use the bathroom that morning,  and so naturally I pick up the wallet and called my manager right away, who happened to be off that day.  She did not answer,  I'm thinking i would be in a panic if i lost my wallet. The wallet snaps together like a book, so so i opened it, NEVER went through it but i could clearly see multiple 100 dollar bills, drivers ID, social security card, credit cards.... It belonged to one of the painters.   My manager finally calls back and I inform her,  she reaches to the guy to let him know.    Well instead of being grateful he was FURIOUS  that it was opened.   I was NEVER thanked, infact i was called into my managers office to be "talked to"  I obviously didn't take anything,  didn't write down any important info, Heck i forgot his name just an hour later...  How else where we suppose to identify the owner?  Xray vision? Just glad some people appreciate honest people,  because that almost never made me want to help a stranger again. Seriously,  how can i be reprimanded for doing what i thought was a good deed.  Just awful....

husband speaking age 81.8  I worked for the U.S. Postoffice for 35 years.  You would not believe how many lost or stolen purses or wallets end up in the drop box of the Post Office.  Get rid of the evidence - drop in the mail.  We ( Post Office ) will try to return the item to the ADDRESS ON THE DRIVERS LICENSE, which is usually WRONG.  If you move and do not want to go to the DMV to change your address, at least write a new address on a piece of paper and tape to your license.

Few years ago I was driving home from work and when approaching a red light the passenger in an industrial work truck in front of me got out and climbed this ladder into the back and then climbed out to get back in the truck before the light turned. As he was getting climbing in I saw his phone fall right out of his back pocket, and he didnt notice. Even when he climbed out.  So I followed him about a mile down the road to a roundabout to see which way he was going to turn, I then turned around to see if his phone was not only still there but hopefully undamaged by other vehicles that could have it over. To my suprise, his phone was still where it fell and completely fine! I then drove back down to the roundabout and turned where I last saw him turn, as I turned they were coming down the street, (probably going back to find his phone) I honked my horn waving his phone out the window to get their attention.  He was so grateful I retrieved his phone and sought him out to return it. ğŸ˜Š

My father found on a table what he thought was a camera case then when he and his family went to eat they looked in it to see if they could find an ID. They ended up finding over $20,000 plus another $10,000 in lira which was Italian money. He got home and called the police, and they flipped out stating that it was report stolen but they had a feeling they had lost it instead. They came to pick it up and the officers were just amazed that my father had called it in, and he just stated it was not his to keep. I have always returned anything I have found including wallets and our family still has this instilled into us.

As a kid ( over 40 years ago) i once found a wallet with nearly Â£500 in it, id never seen that much money in my life before, in fact id never seen more than Â£20 at the time, so i took it to the police station and handed it in. A few weeks went by and i got a letter asking to attend the police starion. I was really worried thinking id done something really bad, but when i arrived the police took me into a room where an old couple were sitting and it turned out to be the owner of the wallet, they were so very very grateful and wanted to personally hand me a card to say a huge thank you. When i opened it up there was Â£150 inside. I gave Â£100 to my mum and gave each of my sibblings Â£10 each. So not only dod it make me feel good about doing the right thing and handing in the wallet but i was then also able to help my family out and me and my sibblings also got to go to the toy store and get an unexpected treat. Doing the right thing has always made me smile. P.s the old couple that rhe money belonged to was for urgent veterinary care for their long term family dog, without handing that money in, he would have had to be put down. X
I would do the same thing no greed or jealousy from my part
When i was 9 I could have had a hundred or so if I was sneaky. But, how would I explain it to my parents? So I showed them the purse I found on the road and the money I picked up leading up to it (friends said they'd seen it on the roof of a car driving). All told, about $200. They found the address on whatever ID was inside and organised the postage. A couple of months later a letter, card and $20 were in the letterbox as a thankyou. For a nine-year old in 1984 twenty dollars was quite the lump sum.

I had the emcee make an announcement about a lost item.  A woman that reminded me of my beloved granny found me and she described  the bracelet down to the Harry Winston hallmark. I was walking home when I was in the 7th grade and when I was crossing the grass in front of the building next door I saw a purse and all it's contents just strewn all over, like there was a trail of stuff leading to the purse, I saw it, kept walking, stopped, walked back, started walking, stopped, walked back, I wasn't sure what to do, do I just leave it, or do I pick it up, so I picked it up, grabbed all the stuff that was laying on the ground, I'm talking like everything, napkins, toothpicks, everything, and I took it home. I guess I could have just walked back to school but that didn't even cross my mind, I thought I'd take it home and figure out who it belonged to. So we did, my grandfather looked inside, found the address, and we went to the house which was 1968 Foxworthy Ave in San Jose, I still remember that because that's the year I was born, so it wasn't too hard to remember, but we knocked on the door, she opened it, was totally shocked that this fat 12 year old was standing there holding her purse, she told  my grandfather that it had been stolen off the back of her chair, I gave it back to her and she was like, "hold on a minute, I'll be right back" she came back and gave me a five dollar bill, I still feel guilty about taking it to this day, and that was in 1981, but I should have just gave it to her, said "no, that's ok" to the money and walk away, instead I took it and I still remember saying to myself, "that's it?" I still laugh at the memory.

About a year ago I found a purse behind my restaurant. It had around $650 in cash and a cashier's check for if I remember right $1200. I couldn't find the person on social media she had a common name. The Yellow Pages had a listing for that name. It ended up being her mom. She said she accused her daughter of being back on drugs because that was her rent money. She had called the mom crying asking for money for her rent. The mom cried on the phone telling me she accused her daughter of being on drugs and being a bad mother to her children. When the daughter came to pick her purse up she tried to give me money and then my children money. I told her it was more important for me to teach my children to do right rather than to take any money. She kept telling me how great I am. I told her it doesn't take a great person to not steal someone else's money. That money wasn't mine and would have brought bad karma anyways.  But that teenage boy is a great young man for this. He's only 17 and I'm sure could use the money. But made the right choice. He must have great parents or great role models.

I was blind drunk on a stag night in London, somehow got home, but had lost my wallet - obviously I had to cancel all my cards etc... about 6 weeks later I get a call from London Underground, saying they have it... Honestly I really didn't thing it would be worth going to get. But I did... and it still had over Â£100 in cash, all my cards, even an engagement ring (different story)... it was all there. I thought about it afterwards - That lost wallet must have passed between at least 4 people, probably 7.... None of them took it, although it would have been very, very easy to do so. I asked for the details of the person who handed it in - I was going to give them a few hundred for... well - total honesty. But I was told "that is confidential". Very annoying. I gave the contents of the wallet to a homeless charity - I'd already lost it. The ring is another matter. :)

It pays to be honest because they probably would have killed me for that stash.

In a completely empty isle of a grocery store, I found 2 twenty dollar bills on the floor. I looked around and picked them up and put them in my pocket and finished shopping. I got home and inspected them and saw they were wrapped up in an ATM withdrawal slip from an account with only a couple hundred dollars in it. I went to the bank a few days later when it was open and said I was there to return the money and they were shocked. They gave me a few pens, a little eyeglass cloth, and a starbucks gift card with no funds on it. (Bank manager said she wasn't sure if it had money but wanted to give me something). I left my email address in case they wanted to contact me or something. The girl whose money I returned ended up getting in touch and left me a nice card with a $50 bill in my mailbox!

Nicely done, young man. When I was about his age, I did the same. I was walking home and found a wallet and its belongings scattered across an intersection. I gathered up all of the items, and called the lady. When we met, she kept looking at me and around to see if there were others hiding somewhere, lol. She tried to give me some money but I told her is was not necessary. She was just absolutely in shock. I really didn't think much of it. Just trying to do the right thing.

I did the same thing when I was a kid. I found her purse under some debris in the woods. I was using a metal detector. I walked over to her address and returned her property. She told me she was relieved as her social security card and other things were in the purse and the thief only seemed to be after the cash. She asked me where I lived, I assumed to recieve a letter or something. Every day after school I checked the mailbox out of excitement, to hear back from her. Nothing ever came. I guess as a kid I needed a little affirmation. What these women did for him is very special. They wanted him to know how much that gesture meant to them. And those around them. Very cool

Many years ago I was jobless and about 2 weeks from being homeless. I found a wallet at a filling station, it had enough money in it to pay my rent and a bit left over for food.  It was someones whole paycheck. Or so I thought.  I looked up his number, white pages there were no cell phones in those days, and called him. Let him know i had his wallet and he should come get it.  Well, long story short.  He owned a lawn maintenance company. I had explained my circumstances and he hired me on the spot.  I worked for him for several years before we both went our separate ways.. all amicable.  He was a very good boss.
Never judge a book by itâ€™s cover.

Yes, definitely there's still good ppl in this world and this young man is prove of that.  Back in the early 90s I found this wallet at a train station in NYC. I immediatelly looked for some ID with a phone #  to see if I could give it back to its owner. I found a veteran hospital ID card with a pic of an elderly man, some other papers and $15 in cash. No phone # but it had a postal address in Queens. I thought about sending it through the mail but without my address bc I didn't want to be compensated. I just wanted to make sure he got his wallet, with his money and everything else he had in it and that was it.  Then I thought about the possibility of this person not living there any longer and his wallet getting lost so I put my return address just in case.  Two weeks later I got a letter in the mail with a note from this person thanking me for my gesture, saying something to the effect of "you're a very decent person, not many ppl would take the time to do what you did". It also included a money order for $30, just what I was trying to avoid when I thought about not including my address on the package. I sent him his $15 and he sent me $30.  That's what I was taught at home when I was a kid  and that's how I still am at 65 yrs old.
In addition, he saw the picture on the ID, and said, yoooo....she fine af. Lol
stay the course young man.  You will live a rich life.

In a test a few years back wallets were left on the street to see how often, of at , they would be returned. All the major cities were k course, a percentage of returns tracked at each   In only one major city was the wallet * always * returned, doing better than medium and small towns tested.  Chicago. All the wallets were returned in Chicago.

I once found a purse on the side of the road. I called up the people that it belonged to and arranged a time for them to collect it as their address wasn't to be found on the purse for me to go to their house to return it. WHAT ???????  $19,000   Thats fantastic , good luck to him .
Way back in 1980 I was in the Royal Navy. One evening my ship went into Torquay and I went ashore for a few drinks with my shipmates. While they went to the first pub, I took the opportunity to go to a phone booth and speak to my brother; then I joined my mates in the pub. The next round of drinks were my turn but I realised I'd left my wallet on the shelf in the phone booth so rushed back ... but it wasn't there of course. I borrowed money from one of the other guys to pay for my round and we continued our run ashore. At the end of the evening we went back onboard and as I came across the gangway, the bosuns mate handed me my wallet. He told me "Some civvy found it and saw the Navy ID card inside and brought it to the ship". All of the contents (money, cards, photographs etc.) were there and the person who returned it didn't even leave their name for me to thank them. All these years later I still remember that act of kindness and sincerely hope there is such a thing as Karma because they deserve very good things in their life.

It bothers me when people say things like "there's hope for the younger generation" as if the younger generation was hopeless, that doing good things is rare for them, or they're destined to turn out badly.   They're not. The majority of the younger generation will chose to do what they think is the right thing, whether that's bringing it to the person's door or handing it in at the police station. Each generation says the same thing about the next generation, as if the next gen is growing up without morals and values. The morals and values may be different to what our parents taught us, but that's just how it's always been.   I'm a younger millennial, but I love what I've seen of Gen Z so far. They're so funny and clever, they're not afraid to stand up for what is right, they're more accepting of people, they're not afraid of being themselves, or talking about difficult or taboo subjects. I think they're brilliant, and they've got a great future ahead of them. They have a lot of potential to change things for the better, especially when it comes to school shootings, mental health, and the environment.

I found a lost wallet once outside a grocery market. It was filled with cash. For sure thousands. And credit, debit cards with tap. I immediately looked in the wallet to find a drivers license with an address so I could return it. I put the address into google maps and returned it straight away. Once I got to the house, I knocked on the door and the man was on the phone with the RCMP in attempt to help him find his lost wallet. He looked very worried. I told him I had his wallet, returned it into his hands and he was shocked to see everything was exactly there still, nothing stolen. He handed me a wad of cash. It was a couple of hundred dollars. I split that with my boyfriend who also helped me return the wallet.  I knew god/the universe sent me to be the one to find the wallet because I would never steal and the good karma was instantly returned â¤

My son found a woman's purse on a trail between houses in our neighborhood. He came home and we called the person as their info was on their checks in a checkbook. Her daughter came to pick it up. It just so happened that the daughter worked at the public defender's office, in juvenile division. She asked my son numerous questions and asked what he had done with the money. She all but accused him of stealing her mother's purse. He got scared until I had to step in and tell her to take the purse and leave. He didn't take anything and I didn't appreciate her accusing him with no evidence. She certainly wasn't appreciating the fact that her mother got everything back, except for a little money, I gather. It really soured him, but, we helped him realize that some people just can't be decent or grateful. Too bad some of those people work with children.

One time I was at the grocery store and this elderly gentleman was paying for his groceries. He opened his wallet to pull out his cash and while doing this half of a large portion of that cash fell on the floor mostly hundreds and if I were to guess would say a it was over 5 grand. No one saw but me and my daughter not even the cashier I tried to get his attention i as he was walking away because I  didn't want his saying any cash was missing but he ignored me like I was bothering him. He kept walking so I picked up the cash and walked up to him and tapped him on his shoulder and said excuse me Sr you dropped some cash. He turned around and didn't say a word snatched the money out of my hand turned around and walked away like he didn't even care if he lost it. I remember the cashier looking at the cash in amazement of the amount and my daughter telling me you should have kept it dad. I turned to her and said I didn't return it for him I returned it for me. She looked confused but I know the influence was worth the loss that that money could have helped my situation at the time. Needless to say we got through being broke, we did not die, my life turned out great, and my daughter learned a quality that is priceless Honesty!

No good deed goes unpunished...yesterday that saying was myth busted. This construction worker left his $1,203.92 expensive smartphone in a bathroom stall at a restaurant and was found by a customer who took it and left. He looked through the phone at a local park and didn't care for the phone much(since he thought to himself that it might have a tracker app installed) so he was about to throw it in the park's trash can but something in the back of his mind told him to go back to the restaurant and wait. So he did and 8 minutes after arrivng there, the smartphone rang. It was the owner and he told him that he needed the phone back because it had all his important business phone number contacts and that he would reward him if he got his phone back undamaged. They met in front of the restaurant and he handed over the phone...no cops were involved. And after inspecting the smartphone he then decided to reward that guy with $880.00 cash. Some times it does pay off to be honest.

Found a purse 3 years ago before work early and decided to get it to the police since the home of the guy was pretty far away and i was with my bike. At first an officer got angry with me for putting my bike at the wrong place at the police station (that one is on me) and the officer inside got angry with me for bringing it to the police and not to the district courts mailbox (i had no idea you can do that stuff, but appearently its the right thing to do). Felt pretty awful afterwards for doing "the right" thing. :/  Funfact: A week after the press of the police published an article about "good deeds in our town" about two boys finding a phone and bringing it to the police and how great and awesome this is.  But still, i got a call from the owner and he thanked me a lot and thats all that matters right?  Story from germany :)

LOL like the taxi driver in GermanyğŸ˜…:  In Germany, and beyond,  is making headlines a story that has as protagonist Manuel Neuer, goalkeeper of Bayern Munich and the German national team. The "case" took place a few weeks ago, when the footballer and a friend got into a taxi in central Munich to make a transfer. At the end of the ride, the taxi driver noticed that Neuer's wallet was in the rear seats of the car, with 800 euros in cash, various documents and bank cards. Imagining that he was doing a favor, the man decided to go on a journey to return the wallet to the owner. Not finding him in the last destination where he had accompanied him, the taxi driver headed to the official address of Neuer, driving for 120km.  The taxi driver, who had spent almost 400 euros for that trip, expected something for the "disturbance" or at least that the footballer would offer to pay the gasoline costs. The Bayern captain, on the other hand, would have repaid by sending the taxi driver a shirt of with his name printed from the German champion club.   "Two weeks later I received a Bayern Munich shirt, personalized with his name, but without a dedication or thank-you note. The reward is a mockery. I have four children."

When my son was 17 he found a very fat wallet with over $15,000 cash in it in a grocery store parking lot where he worked.  He took it in to management and they were able to get it back to the owner who said he had stopped at the store on his way to buy a car with cash.  The guy was shocked that my son returned it and tried to give him a cash reward but my son refused to accept it. He couldn't understand why he should be rewarded for doing what "anyone" would do. Very proud day for us as parents.  To be clear, I would have been just as proud even if he did accept the cash reward. I am certain that Adrian didn't do the good deed expecting a reward but I am happy for him that the people were able to raise one for him.

my husband dropped his wallet on a bus while travelling to work in Mississauga, Ontario Canada and we were so stressed out as he had his SIN card (Social security), health card, all his credit cards etc, and we were so concerned of identity theft and having to cancel all his cards. Then about 1 week later, we got a knock on the door around 10pm on a Sunday evening with a policeman asking  for his name and confirming his personal info and then handed over his wallet. Someone had found it on the bus and dropped if off at a nearby police station. We were both shocked and truly grateful that a good Samaritan had done this great deed, and so grateful for the policeman going out of his way to personally drop off my husband's wallet.

test
Reminds me of a quote, "The true test of a man's character is what he does when no one is watching." - John Wooden
When I was in college I was pulling away from a convenience store on my motorcycle when I noticed a leather wallet on the ground. Opening it up I found a little over $50 and a food stamp book. The ID was of an older black man. There was no phone number but there was an address. This was obviously a person who couldn't afford to lose the 50. let alone the various ID cards. I was hurting for money at the time but it never occurred to me to do anything other than return it to its owner. The neighborhood was rundown and sketchy. I rang the doorbell and explained about the wallet. The man, his children, and grandchildren were there.   They were so kind and grateful. I was rewarded with a wash of neurochemicals that made me feel as good as a drug rush. Doing the right thing, helping people, FEELS good. They told me I must be a Christian to have done such a nice thing. I felt even better when I told them I was an atheist and this shows how one needn't be motivated by religion to want to do the right thing. After a group hug I left, feeling really good. I don't believe in Karma but not long after I left my wallet with a similar amount of money in a phone booth. I  returned the next day to a nearby convenience store. Sure enough, an antonymous person had turned in the wallet.

A few years ago I found a purse in Amsterdam. It was from a tourist (they were sitting next to me at the fountain in front of the Rijksmuseum and had left a few minutes before I noticed the purse), so I went to the police station to return it. Police was surprised that all the money (a few hundred Euro) was still in there. It never crossed my mind to take the money out and I just wanted them to get their credit cards and ID back, as it can be a huge pain to lose those (especially in a foreign country).  I never heard back from police, so I expect the tourists to have gotten it back.

When I was 16 I was riding my bike to the gas station when I found an envelope on the ground. Upon opening it I realized it was a check for $1,600 dollars. I looked around but saw no one, so I examined the paper more closely and identified an address. I used to work at Pizza Hut and one night I found a wallet in the front carryout area where people place their order. I showed some of my co-workers the wallet and a couple of them wanted to go through it and see if there was any money. I refused to let them go through the wallet, and ended up tracking down the owner of it through social media. He came by the next day and picked it up, thanking me wholeheartedly. He opened up his wallet, took out a hundred dollar bill and handed it to me. I said "No thanks man, don't worry about it." He then said "You're a good dude" and offered me a $5 instead which I accepted.

A good example of why you should never judge a book by its cover. I used to dress similar in high school, baggy sagging pants, backwards hat, etc. and I've actually had people act like I was going to steal something and just generally treat me like I was a scumbag for no reason, even going as far as calling the police. The cop that showed up literally said that someone called on us because my friends and I "looked like lowlifes that were up to no good." All we were doing was walking to a friends house after school, and in actuality we were all good students who rarely got into even minor trouble. One of the friends that was with me is actually a cop now and told me that he gets tons of calls for stuff like that. He told me that one time he got called out for some kids hanging out skateboarding in an empty parking lot. He said he showed up, talked to the kids for a few minutes, did a kickflip in uniform and then proceeded to tell the lady that called that they were well mannered and were doing nothing wrong and "could be out committing real crimes, getting high, or playing video games inside all day long." I love seeing people do good like this, and honestly this kid is a better person than many adults twice his age.

About five years ago, I had just moved to a new city by myself. It was my first time living on my own and paying all my own bills. I was a waitress at the time and had gotten home late after a busy Friday night at work. The next morning, rent was due and my wallet with 850$ in cash in it was missing.  I only found this out because the office at my apartment complex called me to say someone turned had turned it in.  I was SHOCKED to say the least because I didn't know I had dropped my wallet and I didn't have any other money to pay my rent. I go up to the office to get my wallet just knowing all my cash was gone and there it was. All 850$! Due to privacy laws, they couldn't give me the woman's name who turned it in but the office said they could give her something from me.  I got her a thank you card with a giftcard in it and left my phone number.  She called me to thank me and we ended up being great friends. When I thanked her for my wallet she said "of course. Why would I take it. It's not mine. â¤ï¸

This happened to me before. It was actually my 18th birthday and I'd gone to the mall with my family. I ended up leaving my wallet in the bathroom stall and didn't realize it. I didn't even know I'd left my wallet until I got home hours later. I called the mall and told them I'd left it in the bathroom. They took my number and a description of the wallet and told me they'd reach out if anyone found it. I honestly had no hope in getting it back at all so I freaked out and cried the rest of the day for my birthday. The next day I got a call back from some old lady who said she'd found my wallet and wanted to return it to me. It ended up being that all my money, cards and social were still in there untouched. The old lady made me meet her in public to see my face to make sure it was really mine. I'll always be thankful to that woman I'm sure by now she's probably dead but she really saved me from having my identity stolen and worse.

I find every year on average two wallets, on the street. It's so ridiculous my friends joke about it. Every single time I take my time to find the person on social media, meet up somewhere and give it back. About 90 percent of the time it's a post box I drop it into, once a guy was picky and unavailable to meet, wanted me to go bring it to his place further away (!!) ... and of course , I get nada, because gratitude is a lost word. And in Belgium if you hand it in to the police, they have to destroy your ID , even of you present yourself to claim it, but people don't realize how much I help them. Oh well... off to find another wallet.

I also did this, twice. First time it was a purse left in a public phone box. Lots of cash within plus driving licence etc. There was also a phone number which I called and arranged a time when I'd call round to return the purse. When I arrived at the house the owner of the purse wasn't home ( although she knew I was coming )instead her flatmate opened the door, thanked me saying owner wasn't home and slammed the door on me. Second time I found a businessman's wallet on the exit of an underground garage. Usual documents and cash inside + phone number. Called the number and explained I had the wallet but owner wasn't available. ( this took several calls ). I left my number for the owner to contact me which he did an hour or so later. Turned up in a Porsche 911, met me, thanked me and gave me his business card and got back into his Porsche and drove off. Perhaps I had been expecting too much but I didn't have the luck for my good deeds the kid in this video had!

My mum, who is 80, did the same when she found a lady's bag on a bench in a park. She took the bag home with her and asked a neighbour to call a "husband" (contact on the phone that was in the bag) because she can't use a smart phone herself. The neighbour gave them my mother's address and soon both the owner of the bag and her husband showed at my mother's door and collected the bag. As a sign of gratitude they gifted my mom a lovely set of six ice-cream bowls with matching spoons.

I also found a rich womans handbag. It was in the middle of busy main road. I stopped car jumped out and ran over and grabbed it and ran back to car, lucky not to hold up any traffic. Must have looked like a lunatic. She had EVERYTHING in there.  I pulled over at supermarket and phoned up some company numbers on her cards and told them to give her a ring and tell her to ring me. 5 mins later she rings and I arrange to meet her where I am at the supermarket carpark.  She takes 20-30 minutes, but I dont mind waiting as I look forward to my praise and hopefully nice reward.  She arrives and gets her bag back, thanks me like its nothing and drives off. Wheres my $3000? The reason I did it was because Ive lost wallets before and just wished so much that whoever found it would just contact me. Keep the cash - I dont even care - just give my wallet and personal cards and stuff back.  Also found 2 cell phones belonging to 20 year old students that I messaged online to find. Neither gave any reward but they were just poor students.

This reminds me of the time I found a wallet lying in the field behind the Whitby City Hall. I took it home, tried to find out the name of the person using the Internet, but didn't know what to do. I eventually called the police, and conversed with them. One thing led to another, and they opted to come, take the wallet, and return it to the proper owner.   While there, I gave the black cop some advice to tell the owner. There's a built-in hole in the wallet for a string to go through, so buy a black shoestring, and use it to secure it to your belt so you'll never lose it again. While I didn't get any reward, I just don't care. I wanted to give the person their wallet they lost, and the police were helpful.   Thank you Durham Regional Police Service.

This exact situation happened to me. I forgot my purse in a cart after a very long day at work (worked overtime that day). I was exhausted but had to get some groceries that day. So when hubby picked me up, I had him load everything in to the car while I sat down. He thought I had my purse, I thought he'd put it in the trunk. Panic set in the moment I got home and realized and we raced back to the store. But no one had turned it in. I assumed it was gone forever, but some kind person found it and brought it to my apartment building and gave it to our superintendent while we were racing back to the store. I have no idea who is was and the Super didn't get their name or address. Everything was still inside. Bless them.  This was many years ago now.

I taught my son who is 20 yrs old just to do the right thing & be considerate of others. About 2 years ago, my son found a young woman's wallet on the busy street about 2 miles from my home. He came home & showed me the wallet & then we looked at her license.  I found her name on Facebook & I dm to her. We met up at the gas station right around the corner from my house. She was very thankful & grateful. She lost her wallet while riding her bike. She pulled out her phone from her pocket & then her wallet fell off. She had everything that was in her wallet.  She did offer us a ride home but we lived about 2 blocks, so there's no need. No reward needed bc I just think she finally got it back & no need to start all over again. That's the reward.   There should be humanity in this world & all we have to do just keep believing it. Great job young man! Btw, it happened in New Orleans, so just keep believe that there's humanity & consideration in this crazy ass city!

many years ago I found someone's $2,000. Louis Vuitton wallet and it had about $50, an ID card from Australia and some credit cards. I tried desperately to return the wallet to the woman, no luck. I contacted the issuing banks of the cards in her wallet and they wouldn't relay a message to her. So I had to write a letter to the address on her Australian ID and maybe a month and a half later I get a call from the girl and was able to return her wallet. she was grateful and shocked and it was great to be able to return it.

Good parenting! Its so important to not just tell your kids its wrong but make them understand why. My grandmother told me when she was a kid during the days of the depression in the 30's she found a purse with lots of money in it. Even though her own family barely had money for food, she returned it. It turned out it contained the persons entire months grocery money. The lady ended up baking pies and food for my grandmothers family many times thereafter.  This story stuck with me forever, and it did make me choose to do the right thing a few times after instead of being opportunistic. RIP Nana, the most loving and wholesome woman Ive ever known.

A few years ago, my son went to a yearly parade and festival in our home town for the first time without me to just hang out with some friends.  I received a phone call from a young man saying he found a wallet with my name and number in it for emergencies.  He said he had found it on the ground by a food vendor truck and could bring it to me if I wanted.  I had him wait till I called my son and merged the calls.  Since they were both still at the event, they were able to find each other.   Now this young man couldâ€™ve taken the money and said thatâ€™s the way he found it or not even contacted me at all, but every dollar was accounted for!  My son had just cashed his very first paycheck from his first after school job, so it meant a lot to him.  My son wanted to give him a reward, but he wouldnâ€™t take one, just asking him to pay it forward when he could.  To be honest & not trying to brag, I have seen my son pay it forward several times since then and am so proud!

It's always a positive when people carry out considerate acts but it's also a reflection on society when we feel the urge to reward even the simplest acts with thousands of dollars, viral videos, gushing comments and tv news features. It feels we expect so little of each other that when we see virtue we go overboard. Recently, a man giving someone $5 ended up being rewarded with over $100k. Anyone seeing that may become resentful when their own kind act isn't rewarded similarly. Or people may be carrying out virtuous acts in anticipation of the large rewards they may receive. I don't think we do people favors by over-rewarding and we should keep some semblance of moderation in mind. Virtue is, as they say, its own reward.

That happened to my wife and I this weekend. We had to hit the ATM and we found a wallet with a elderly ladies credit cards, bank cards and her drivers license on the side of the ATM. She only lived about 10 blocks from us so we took it back to her. The only difference is her daughter accused my wife of pick pocketing this lady. We did not know her, we did not see her, it was just her wallet at the side of the ATM. Then her daughter accused my wife of stealing $2000.00 for the inside of her purse. That is when the elderly lady told her daughter to shut up and stop making up stories. I guess her daughter stole her moms wallet, went to the ATM and took out $2000.00 and forgot where she left her mothers wallet. I told my wife that if it ever happens again just to leave it there and do not touch it.

I know things like this happen...but one time when I was in management at Wendy's a woman left a purse in the lobby. I found it under the table while cleaning. I brought it into my office and decided to find her ID to call her...in her purse was 50,000 dollars (I know how much it was because the withdraw slip was banded around it)...  I found the ID after seeing that and I knew I had to keep my mouth shut and lock it in the office. I used the ID to find her called her and asked her if she left her purse in our lobby to make sure I found the right person. I told her I used her ID to find her so I could get it back to her as fast as I could...and that I knew I had to keep it locked in the safe.   She came and picked it, didn't say thank you, didn't act like she cared that nothing was missing despite I could have easily gotten somebody who didn't work there to "find the purse" and bounce with it. She acted like it was an inconvenience she had to come back to get it...   I just wanted her to say thank you...screw the tip...just show me you appreciated it... because I've lost my wallet 3 times in my life and none of them were returned, and I had money in there...I've had other lesser things happen where I did good deeds and I was not shown any appreciation for it...so it's caused me to become a bit sour. Like why should I even care anymore?

I've returned someone's wallet before. I worked at a golf course, saw it in a cart I was cleaning, and temporarily stored it in my pocket for safe keeping. I somehow forgot to turn it in to the pro shop before we closed for the day, so I drove roughly twenty miles extra to return the wallet to the address listed on the driver's license. I was rewarded with $20, but what I _really_ cared about was the fact that I no longer had to feel guilty about taking a stranger's wallet home with me, even if it was just an accident. ğŸ¤£

Love these stories. Im 30 and live in Indianapolis IN. And I have never lost my wallet before. But about a month ago. I got off work really late and needed to go to Kroger. And I did that. And from being so tired. I was in a rush and left my wallet on the self checkout area. And I have a metal ridge wallet. But sadly I didn't realize l left my wallet for about a hr. So someone could had literally spent thousands. Because I'm not rich ag all. But had 4 credit cards and bank card. So I locked all my cards and had maybe 80 dollars cash in it. Ran back to Kroger and they were already in closed. But the cop that does security was nice to let look real fast. But it was gone. Literally 5 days later my neighbor knocks on my door and days a man was looking for your house he found your wallet and wanted to return it. And my neighbor just said yea I know him and I'll give him his wallet and the man said thanks. It blew me away Literally. My 80 dollars all my cards my gun permit etc was still in it. And I just wish I could have seen the man I even told my neighbor. I wish he would have seen my house and I would have atleast gave him that 80 dollars literally.  Because getting my ID,,gun permit,4 credit cards and my bank card alone would take a good amount of time. And on that 5th day I took work off to get it all done. Yet that morning some man returned my wallet but sadly instead of my neighbor pointing him to my house she took it. And that's not her fault glad she did and she's a good neighbor. But I wanted to reward the man. Especially since I live in the hood and lost my wallet at a hood Kroger. So it shows that we still still do have good honest people in the world. I did post on my Facebook etc and told the story hoping he would see it. But no luck.

I actually found 1500.00 USD in a Ziploc back inside a brown paper bag stuffed down in a planter outside an apartment complex while resting during a summer move of a client. I had very young subordinates working with me on that move so, I explained to them to always do the right thing even when no one is watching. Afterwards we drove over to the nearby police station and turned the money in. We were told if no one claims the money after 90 days then we could claim the money as found. It kinda became a daily routine in our workplace to inquire about the status of the found money as we counted down the days. I'd even call the PD from time to time to see if the money had been claimed. On the 90th day, my assistant called the PD and was told, "Oh, that money was claimed months ago... sorry." I thought this was a bit odd since I had been calling and was told no claim had been made throughout the entire 90 days. I told my assistant not to tell the rest of the shift and I actually ponied up 1500.00 myself and told her to pretend she went to the PD to get the money. Everyone was so excited. I took "the money" and everyone on shift out to Red Lobster that night. Team building, yay. But I always wondered to this day what actually happened to that 1500.00 USD found in a Ziploc bad stuffed down inside a planter outside an apartment complex.

Last year, I found a man's wallet in a parking lot of a restaurant. I thought about dropping the wallet off at the restaurant but decided to hand deliver the wallet to the owner to make sure it got returned to him. It had his ID, other cards and money inside. Said he was a veteran.  It took me a while to find his apartment, but I eventually found it. I knocked on his door and asked if he was "so and so" and he replied that he was. I told him that I had found his wallet and was returning it to him. The look on his face, he told me he thought he had lost it for good and even called the restaurant. He offered $20 but I didn't accept it. I just wanted to make sure that it got returned to the right owner and would like for someone to do the same for me. The smile on his face was more than enough.

Here in Ghana a taxi driver returned   GhÂ¢8400.00( $1041.15) to a passenger who was a business woman. The woman mistakenly left her money in the car probably after hectic Friday  work. During the weekend the woman wept uncontrollably and was being consoled by her sisters not knowing how she lost the money. The money was also not solely hers making her so dreadful of what will happen next. Miraculously on the following Monday, the taxi driver, who knew the woman as a regular customer returned to the woman's house with the full money. She couldn't believe it, she wept and bowed in front of the honest driver to thank him for his magnanimity, it was absolutely emotional and beautiful to onlookers and people who saw it on social media. The honest cab driver has  recieved almost GhÂ¢50,000($6,197.30) sum of money from funds made for him, a renowned Pentecost church, recieved money also from some celebrities and some politicians here in Ghana. The real story here is that this is a story. I'm sorry to be a stone in the shoe, but... It's a problem that this isn't the norm anymore. I moved last year from a capital city to a small town, and the culture shock of not having to watch over my belongings anymore is still not entirely settled in. I lock my front door only because I discovered that it's so old that if I don't, I'll return home to a wide open door. No one steals or rips my bikes. I'm old enough to remember it being this way, even in a smaller city, but honesty is gone now most places. I'm 45. Interestingly, if you travel to Japan, you'll find the same honesty and community awareness, even in a mega city like Tokyo, so it's not scale. We're doing something wrong. I'm glad this boy was brought up well, and I hope his parents aren't proud, just "of course he did, he's not a criminal," and that the purse owner and her friend invited him in for cookies and a hug. Not that I was looking for a reward or anything - but I was once in a mall and this dude dropped his wallet without realizing it. The dude was LOADED! Hundred-dollar bills were falling out on the floor. I didn't hesitate - I scooped up his wallet and shoved every last bill into his wallet without counting it - rushed to the man's side and have him his wallet. He never said so much as "thanks". He just grabbed his wallet and moved on. A Thank you would have been all the reward I would have expected. But nope. Since then I lost my wallet twice over the years and each time someone held the wallet for me - and I am not loaded with money by any stretch of the imagination, but I always thanked the person and praised them for being such honest persons. YES - I will still do the right thing should I find a purse or wallet. I don't want the money. A thank you is great. If I don't get that thank you? Well - I did what was right and I can live with myself even without the thank you.

I have a large wallet that was given to me by my daughter's grandmother at Christmas thirty-one years ago.  I have lost it twice.  Once I left it on the counter at an airport after showing my ID to the gal behind the counter before rushing off to make my plane.  I thought I had left it on the plane and considered it lost until I received a package in the mail from the airline.  The second time was alongside of a road at night when I had stopped to remove a pebble from my shoe.  Again, I considered it lost until I received yet another package in the mail from someone who had found it.  Both times it was returned with nothing missing.

Well,  I found a wallet along with the bank cards and credit cards in the parking lot, so I went to the nearby grocery store and gave it to the manager. I then came home and searched his name on Yellow pages and left a voice message. A few minutes later, he returned my call and I asked him if he lost his wallet. He said yes,  so I asked him to pick it up at that store. I have never forgotten a sincere tone in his voice. Getting ID replacement is such a chaos process though. While I was picking up all the belongings, a woman walked by and I asked her to be a witness when I go to the store.  Instead she asked me to give it to her and she will handle it.  I firmly responded her that it was my obligation to return to the owner myself and just go with me to the store. 2 days later,  I was out from the shopping mall and I dropped my rings in the parking lot.  I wasn't aware when the first one dropped, but the second right had a real stone and I felt a little noise. Then I immediately checked my finger and both rings were gone. I walked back a few steps and found those.  One was given by my mom and another has a Jake on it, both irreplaceable. I shared my friend and good deeds return too soon.

When I was running through the snow the wallet fell out of my pocket and I couldn't find it anywhere. When I thought I was broke and wasn't going to go on vacation I got a phone call from the air force police. Somebody had returned my wallet with all the money still in there. I walked from Greeley Colorado to Brownsville Texas with 57$ on me... first small town in Texas on HWY 385,  I found a wallet by the high way,  I picked it up put it in my backpack... when I got home I went to the post office and bought a big envelope and send the wallet to the owner,  including $11,000 , what I didn't tell you was I lost my last $40i saved to eat... I got home really hungry,  my mother hugged and began to cry,  I have never walked 1320 miles alone... in Christmas I received a letter from Florida with a bank check for $6,000... and a huge thank you note...I walked for 14 days to get home,  but had not eaten in 5 days... it never crossed my mind to take money to eat... I was raised to work if you want something... I was so relieved to be home with my mother...

In my country, recently a guy found old couple savings for an apartment for their kids. The amount was around 70-80 thousand euro, which is a lot for our standards! Later that day he was able to return the money to them! I found a man's wallet in a parking lot when I was 14 and it had $1500 cash in it.  Our across the street neighbor was a fire chief, so he knew the town very well and was able to point us to where the man's license said he lived (this was 1985, so no interwebs).  I rang the doorbell and gave the man the wallet and he said "thanks" and slammed the door.  It was almost like he was TRYING to lose it.  I was taught to try to look past behavior like this because perhaps he had just lost someone, or found out he was sick, or whatever.   LOL.  Anyway, as the young man stated, do the right thing ESPECIALLY when noone is looking.

When I was 17, I lost my wallet on a train in DC, with all my cash and my debit card and drivers license inside. About five hundred dollars cash. I was devastated because I was on a school trip and no longer had any money. I had saved for that trip for an entire year. When I got home, my wallet still full of cash was in the mailbox with no return address. Whomever sent it back to me didn't want any reward or credit for it. It restored my faith in humanity which even at 17 had taken a hit. People can be truly good.

I 've returned 3 cell phones, two wallets and some ID. One cell was equivalent to $2900 in today's money. The delivery guy left it on his roof. The company gave me $100 and wanted it  right away even though I told them I would meet up with them, they came to get it.   A cell phone kept ringing when my friends and I were chatting on a side street near a restaurant we were at. I thought the phone was left on a porch by accident. I rang the doorbell and told the guy he left his phone on the porch. The old guy berated me and told me he would never own such a "new fangled" thing and to take it and go. It rings again and I answer..."Who is this??" "It's the guy who found the phone"  We talked and he showed up with a bottle of wine. They had been at the same restaurant and dropped the phone on the way to the car and a good Samaritan thought it belonged to the grumpy old guy.  The thrid one, I found in a snowbank. I pick it up and it's unlocked. I call "home" no answer. I scroll through the names and lo and behold, I find my friends name in the contact list, so I call him. He answers and we talk a bit and I said "Uhh, whose phone am I calling you from?" It's a hockey buddy. So I told him I have the phone if he talks to him. I go home almost 40 minutes away and then call his house one more time. The wife answers. I told her what happened and she said "OH YEAH? WELL YOU WAIT UNTIL THAT A-HOLE GETS HOME, HE YELLED AT ME FOR LOSING MY PHONE!!" The guy calls me back and I told him where I was. The next day was Christmas and he had to come within minutes of his house to get his mother in law, picked up the phone and gave me $20.  All the other returns were to the right address, but they were young kids that lost their wallets/IDs and their parents took the wallets and IDs while berating their kids and closed the door in my face...

I remember I was at work once and I went outside to the smoking area on my break and there was a wallet sitting on the bench. I opened it up and there was so much cash inside. I get the guy was at the casino but I've never seen anyone carry that much cash in their wallet. Had to be about 4 or 5 grand. The wallet would barely close. Anyway I checked the ID and saw that it was a guy I know. I didn't know him well, basically knew his name and had never had conversation with him beyond maybe a "hi" here and there. Anyway I went inside and saw him and said "Hey Steve you left your wallet outside. He didn't even say "thank you". Haha not because he was a jerk but I think it was because he was so shocked. He just looked at me with a stunned look on his face and his jaw slightly dropped. I was like "alright man cya". He was definitely in shock that someone would return the wallet with so much money inside. Of course I'm NOT a Saint because I honestly don't know what I would have done if the wallet belonged to someone I didn't know. I would like to think I would have returned it but I just don't know. I will say if it was someone I knew who I didn't like because they're a total ass then I wouldn't have returned it. Well, I would have wanted him to get the wallet back so I would have taken the money and left the wallet and im sure someone would have returned the wallet since there was no money inside.
